WhyEN: To a person/recipient is commonly expressed with “at” (not “i”).
WhyCY: At berson/derbynnydd, defnyddir “at” yn aml (nid “i”).

WhyEN: Destination/place you go or send into → “i”.
WhyCY: Cyrchfan/lle (mynd/danfon i mewn iddo) → “i”.

WhyEN: Going to a place → “i” + soft mutation (Caerdydd → Gaerdydd).
WhyCY: Mynd i le → “i” + treiglad meddal (Caerdydd → Gaerdydd).

WhyEN: Appointments/people as a target often take “at”.
WhyCY: At apwyntiad/person fel targed, mae “at” yn gyffredin.

WhyEN: Talking to a person often uses “at”.
WhyCY: Siarad â pherson yn aml → “at”.

WhyEN: Destination/place → “i”.
WhyCY: Cyrchfan/lle → “i”.

WhyEN: Origin/source → “o” + soft mutation (Caerdydd → Gaerdydd).
WhyCY: Tarddiad/ffynhonnell → “o” + treiglad meddal (Caerdydd → Gaerdydd).

WhyEN: “o” triggers soft mutation (Bangor → Fangor).
WhyCY: Mae “o” yn treiglo’n feddal (Bangor → Fangor).

WhyEN: Origin/source → “o”. (Abertawe doesn’t change here.)
WhyCY: Tarddiad/ffynhonnell → “o”. (Does dim newid i Abertawe yma.)

WhyEN: “o” triggers soft mutation (Treorci → Dreorci).
WhyCY: Mae “o” yn treiglo’n feddal (Treorci → Dreorci).

WhyEN: “o” triggers soft mutation (Llanelli → Lanelli).
WhyCY: Mae “o” yn treiglo’n feddal (Llanelli → Lanelli).

WhyEN: Static location “in” → “yn/yng” + nasal mutation (Caerdydd → Nghaerdydd).
WhyCY: Lleoliad “yn” → “yn/yng” + treiglad trwynol (Caerdydd → Nghaerdydd).

WhyEN: “yn” triggers nasal mutation (Bangor → Mangor).
WhyCY: Mae “yn” yn treiglo’n drwynol (Bangor → Mangor).

WhyEN: On a surface/location → “ar”.
WhyCY: Ar arwyneb/lleoliad → “ar”.

PromptEN: My keys are on the table.
WhyEN: On a surface → “ar”.
WhyCY: Ar arwyneb → “ar”.

PromptEN: I’ll see you before the concert.
WhyEN: Before in time → “cyn”.
WhyCY: “Cyn” o ran amser → “cyn”.

WhyEN: After in time → “ar ôl”.
WhyCY: Ar ôl o ran amser → “ar ôl”.

WhyEN: After in time → “ar ôl”.
WhyCY: Ar ôl o ran amser → “ar ôl”.

PromptEN: Park in front of the house.
WhyEN: In front of (place/space) → “o flaen” (not time “cyn”).
WhyCY: O flaen (lleoliad) → “o flaen” (nid amser “cyn”).

PromptEN: The garden is behind the house.
WhyEN: Behind a place/thing → “tu ôl”.
WhyCY: Tu ôl i le/peth → “tu ôl”.

WhyEN: With someone (accompaniment) commonly uses “gyda” + pronoun.
WhyCY: Gyda rhywun (cwmni) yn aml → “gyda” + rhagenw.

WhyEN: Accompaniment → “gyda”.
WhyCY: Cwmni → “gyda”.

WhyEN: “with” in the sense of ‘including’ often uses “gyda”.
WhyCY: “Gyda” am ‘gyda/yn cynnwys’ yn aml → “gyda”.

WhyEN: With feelings/conditions, Welsh often uses inflected “ar”: arna i.
WhyCY: Gyda chyflwr/teimlad, defnyddir “ar” cyfunol: arna i.

WhyEN: Hunger/need commonly uses “ar” inflected with pronouns.
WhyCY: Mae eisiau/newyn yn aml gyda “ar” cyfunol.

WhyEN: Some experiences use “ar” inflected: arni hi.
WhyCY: Mae rhai profiadau gyda “ar” cyfunol: arni hi.

WhyEN: Through/along a space → “drwy/trwy”.
WhyCY: Trwy/ofod → “drwy/trwy”.

PromptEN: She heard it through a friend.
WhyEN: Through a channel/means → “drwy”.
WhyCY: Trwy gyfrwng/sianel → “drwy”.

PromptEN: It was done by the teacher.
WhyEN: Agent (‘by’) is typically “gan”.
WhyCY: Asiant (‘gan’) yn nodweddiadol → “gan”.

WhyEN: Source/agent ‘from/by’ → often “gan”.
WhyCY: Ffynhonnell/asiant ‘gan’ → yn aml “gan”.

WhyEN: At/near a point/place is often “wrth” (context-dependent).
WhyCY: Wrth fan/lle (gerllaw) yn aml → “wrth” (yn dibynnu ar y cyd-destun).

PromptEN: Stay with me (at my place / near me).
WhyEN: “wrth” can mean near/at someone (not accompaniment ‘gyda’).
WhyCY: Gall “wrth” olygu ger/at rywun (nid cwmni ‘gyda’).

WhyEN: Motion ‘into’ → “i” (not static ‘yn’).
WhyCY: Symudiad ‘i mewn’ → “i” (nid lleoliad ‘yn’).

WhyEN: Static location ‘in’ → “yn” (not motion ‘i’).
WhyCY: Lleoliad statig ‘yn’ → “yn” (nid symudiad ‘i’).

WhyEN: About/topic → “am”.
WhyCY: Am bwnc → “am”.

PromptEN: The book is on the table.
WhyEN: On a surface → “ar” (not “am” = about).
WhyCY: Ar arwyneb → “ar” (nid “am” = am bwnc).

PromptEN: We are going to the park now.
WhyEN: Use i for movement to a place or destination.
WhyCY: Defnyddir y rhagferf i er mwyn mynegi symud tuag at le neu gyrchfan.

PromptEN: I am writing to the bank today.
WhyEN: Use at when writing or sending something to a person or institution.
WhyCY: Defnyddir at gyda berfau fel ysgrifennu neu anfon at bobl neu sefydliadau.

PromptEN: Send a text to your sister.
WhyEN: At is used for sending messages to someone rather than to a place.
WhyCY: Defnyddir at i ddangos bod y neges yn mynd at berson nid at le.

PromptEN: The teacher is going to the office after the lesson.
AfterCY: r swyddfa ar ôl y wers.
WhyEN: Here the movement is to a room so we choose i not at.
WhyCY: Yma mae symud tuag at ystafell felly dewiswn i ac nid at.

WhyEN: Use yn to say in a specific place or city.
WhyCY: Defnyddir yn i ddangos bod rhywun neu rywbeth y tu mewn i le penodol fel dinas.

PromptEN: She is going to Cardiff tomorrow.
WhyEN: Use i with verbs of movement for going to a town or city.
WhyCY: Defnyddir i gyda berfau symud pan fydd rhywun yn mynd i dref neu ddinas.

PromptEN: Are you staying in the house tonight?
WhyEN: Yn is used for being inside a place rather than going to it.
WhyCY: Defnyddir yn i ddangos lleoliad y tu mewn i le yn hytrach na symud ato.

PromptEN: They have lived in this village for a long time.
AfterCY: y pentref yma ers amser hir.
WhyEN: Here yn marks the fixed location of their home inside the village.
WhyCY: Yma mae defnyddio yn yn dangos eu cartref fel lleoliad sefydlog yn y pentref.

PromptEN: The book is on the table.
WhyEN: Use ar for something resting on a flat surface like a table.
WhyCY: Defnyddir ar pan mae rhywbeth yn gorffwys ar arwyneb gwastad fel bwrdd.

PromptEN: The keys are in the drawer.
WhyEN: Use yn for something inside an enclosed space like a drawer.
WhyCY: Defnyddir yn pan mae rhywbeth y tu mewn i le caeedig fel drôr.

PromptEN: There is a cat on the roof.
WhyEN: Ar is used for something on top of another thing not inside it.
WhyCY: Defnyddir ar ar gyfer rhywbeth ar ben rhywbeth arall ac nid y tu mewn iddo.

PromptEN: You can find the timetable on the website.
WhyEN: Welsh uses ar for information that is on a screen or on a website.
WhyCY: Yn Gymraeg defnyddir ar ar gyfer gwybodaeth ar sgrin neu ar wefan.

PromptEN: We are talking about the problem.
WhyEN: Am is used to mean about when talking about a topic.
WhyCY: Defnyddir am i olygu am neu ynghylch pan fyddwn yn sôn am bwnc.

PromptEN: The picture is on the wall.
WhyEN: Use ar for something fixed to a vertical surface like a wall.
WhyCY: Defnyddir ar ar gyfer rhywbeth ar wyneb fertigol fel wal.

PromptEN: I am looking for a present for Mam.
WhyEN: Am is used with chwilio to mean look for something.
WhyCY: Defnyddir am ar ôl chwilio i olygu chwilio am rywbeth penodol.

PromptEN: He left his coat on the chair.
WhyEN: Here ar means on a surface so the coat is lying on the chair.
WhyCY: Yma mae ar yn golygu ar wyneb felly mae'r got yn gorwedd ar y gadair.

PromptEN: I have worked here for three years and I still do.
AfterCY: tair blynedd ac yn dal i wneud.
WhyEN: Ers is used with the present or perfect to mean since a point in the past up to now.
WhyCY: Defnyddir ers gyda'r amser presennol neu berffaith i ddangos ers rhyw bwynt yn y gorffennol hyd heddiw.

PromptEN: He stayed in Spain for three years but he is back now.
AfterCY: dair blynedd ond mae e nôl nawr.
WhyEN: Am is used for the whole length of a finished period of time.
WhyCY: Defnyddir am ar gyfer hyd cyfnod sydd drosodd bellach.

PromptEN: I have a bad cold today.
WhyEN: Temporary illnesses and similar states use ar plus a pronoun such as arna i.
WhyCY: Defnyddir ar gyda ffurf wedi ei chydio fel arna i i fynegi cyflwr dros dro fel salwch.

PromptEN: They will be thirsty by the end of the match.
WhyEN: Arnyn nhw is the ar form for they and is used here for a temporary physical state.
WhyCY: Arnyn nhw yw'r ffurf ar ar gyfer nhw ac fe'i defnyddir yma ar gyfer cyflwr corfforol dros dro.
